review_preview: La Posada was recommended by a local as a good non-touristy place to enjoy a good Spanish meal. The restaurant is in a beautiful historic building that is not far from the Plaza Mayor, but the immediately surrounding streets had no obvious tourists. When we...
review_full: La Posada was recommended by a local as a good non-touristy place to enjoy a good Spanish meal. The restaurant is in a beautiful historic building that is not far from the Plaza Mayor, but the immediately surrounding streets had no obvious tourists. When we went in at about 2:00, there was a long list of reservations, but we were promptly seated on the third floor. By 3:00 that large dining area was nearly full, and by the time we left all three dining floors were full. Except for our waiter, who spoke excellent English, we heard only Spanish. Service was prompt and attentive. Our waiter recommended the 1/2 roasted lamb to share for two. Olives and delicious croquettes were brought while we waited for the appetizers, which were excellent, as was the roast lamb. After sharing a very cool flan with ice cream, they brought complimentary dark chocolates. If we return to Madrid, we will return to the Posada de la Villa.

title_review: This restaurant deserves more ratings.  It was first rate!
review_preview: This is a hidden gem.  The reason I say so is that it looks like a closed fortress or inn, not a restaurant.  Many people walk by it without realizing that it is a first class restaurant.  The  management really needs to open its doors...
review_full: This is a hidden gem. The reason I say so is that it looks like a closed fortress or inn, not a restaurant. Many people walk by it without realizing that it is a first class restaurant. The management really needs to open its doors or do something to make it more appealing on the outside. The inside is a different story. What a fabulous, inviting place to relax and eat. It has the ambiance of the several hundred year old inn it once was. The staff were exceedingly kind, friendly and attentive. It is the MOST service oriented restaurant on our entire visit to Spain. I think they put all the good servers in Spain, in this one restaurant. White table cloths. Good chairs. Large basket of variety of bread. Tall glasses of ice water.  Best of all, the food was excellent and plating clearly developed/designed by experienced hands. Lamb is their specialty but we had salmon. It was very well prepared. We saw that many of the other diners were well-dressed Madrid businessmen (2PM). They were among the only men wearing suits, having lunch, we had seen on our trip.  In that old inn, next to the huge fireplace, light coming in through ancient, wavy glass windows, I felt connected to another time before cars, cell phones and zippers in clothing. Enjoy a good meal while in a setting from an earlier time.  Bill: came to 82.90 Euro for 4. Surprisingly low for the quality of the food, ambiance and service. Key: We were given small keys with their name embossed, to remember them by. I'm hanging it on my Christmas tree as a memento of our time in Spain.

title_review: Great Prices and Quality, Not so Great Temps
review_preview: My husband and I ate here after a long day of flights and museums. This tapas bar was within a 4 minute walk of our hotel so we decided to try it. We wanted a small, cheap dinner and this place delivered. We had a...
review_full: My husband and I ate here after a long day of flights and museums. This tapas bar was within a 4 minute walk of our hotel so we decided to try it. We wanted a small, cheap dinner and this place delivered. We had a total of 4 drinks (2 beers, 2 glasses of red wine), and 5 empanadas of varying flavors. The crust on the empanadas was excellent, not too soft, not too hard, perfectly flaky.  Service was quick, but as the first customers at opening time on a Sunday (8pm), I'd hope that was the case. The space is small. Really small. Like, less than 10 tables...so get there early like we did. They filled in fast. It's not on the main tourist corner, either, so it felt more like locals were eating with us. The downside is this place was hot inside - as in my husband and I were both sweating. At the end of a long day that's not necessarily what you want, but the drinks were cold and the food tasty, so what can you do? Our total bill was â‚¬23.10, which was an excellent price for our food and drinks. I recommend this place for anyone looking for small portions and intimate settings.

review_preview: I had my first big meal in Spain at this restaurant and I was impressed!  I ate a lot of really amazing food in Spain so it wasn't the best meal I had overall but it was certainly delicious.  Also, the staff was very attentive...
review_full: I had my first big meal in Spain at this restaurant and I was impressed! I ate a lot of really amazing food in Spain so it wasn't the best meal I had overall but it was certainly delicious. Also, the staff was very attentive and friendly despite the fact that our Spanish is terrible. I also appreciated the rustic decor. We had the following: 1. The lamb - comes in a pan, they chop it up in front of you (noticed all the other tables around us had the lamb too). I don't normally eat lamb but this was quite good. 2. Hake stew (fish) - never had this before. It was good but you have to like seafood. 3. Asparagus - traditional green asparagus we eat in the US. Had asparagus a few other times in Spain and was served the big, white soft kind. 4. Sangria (1/2 pitcher) - wow, so very sweet and thick. Much sweeter than the pseudo sangria I've tried in the US. Had to get used to it. Overall I recommend! This place isn't for the budget conscious though! Quite spendy but totally worth it. I ate here with my mom and my brother and we all enjoyed ourselves.

review_preview: Based on Trip Advisor and other restaurant review sites my husband and I decided to have dinner here last night.  We began with the garlic shrimp.  Bad choice.  The only taste that came through was something akin to distilled white vinegar.  We then followed with...
review_full: Based on Trip Advisor and other restaurant review sites my husband and I decided to have dinner here last night. We began with the garlic shrimp. Bad choice. The only taste that came through was something akin to distilled white vinegar. We then followed with 'peppers podona' (as close to name as I can recall). This was recommended by our waiter after I requested something on the spicy side. While the peppers presented beautifully, looking like a large pile of grilled jalapenos, they tasted like a simple green pepper.....that is, if you were able to get past all the salt! My husband then had the lamb which he seemed pleased with. I opted for the salmon. It was a nice steak cut size. While I had no problem dealing with all the bones, it was the unbelievable amount of salt coating the top of the fish that kept me from finishing the dish.  While the waitstaff was pleasant and attentive, if you are willing to pay over 100 euros for dinner and want to dine near or around Plaza Mayor there are plenty of other restaurants to choose from.

title_review: I'll dream of the lamb forever more

I found the lamb was exquisite in a gourmet yet home-cooked style at the same time. What more could you want? They have a special oven where they crisp the skin yet keep the meat succulent. Worth every dollar spent! Have the Marquis de Riscal Reserva 2005. Perfect match! Rick Steves gave it his two thumbs up, two! Although, the vegetables were way too salty. I suspect the chef smokes and can't taste as well anymore.

title_review: They're Not Just for Making Sweaters Anymore.
review_preview: I ate at Posada de la Villa two nights in a row. The first evening, I attended a large business dinner, which was held in one of the private dining rooms upstairs, and was very impressed with the quality of service, atmosphere, and with my...
review_full: I ate at Posada de la Villa two nights in a row. The first evening, I attended a large business dinner, which was held in one of the private dining rooms upstairs, and was very impressed with the quality of service, atmosphere, and with my meal. But everything had been pre-ordered, and we were on a very tight schedule, so I chose to return the following evening for a more leisurely dinner. I'm so glad I did. Seated at a comfortable table on the first floor, a delicious aroma permeates the dining room from the wood burning oven one floor below. We ordered a few entree's (ham, olives, and shrimp) but were most impressed with the roasted red piquillo peppers - they are delicious. But our main course, the roasted lamb, was sublime. The lamb is designed for two people, like a chateaubriand might be. (I believe the cut is the front leg and shoulder, but don't quote me on that.) The lamb was meltingly tender, with a crisp outer skin. Who knew lamb could taste so amazing. They're not just for making sweaters anymore. The service in the dining room was very good, but tends to suffer just a bit, when large groups (like ours the night before) require service.

title_review: We finally hit the jackpot with this choice
review_preview: After being under-impressed with the service and food in some Madrid establishments, we trekked to this restaurant recommended by Rick Steves.  It has a beautiful, eye-appealing, rustic dining room with an open-beamed ceiling.  Upon arrival, we were greeted very cordially and made to feel very...
review_full: After being under-impressed with the service and food in some Madrid establishments, we trekked to this restaurant recommended by Rick Steves. It has a beautiful, eye-appealing, rustic dining room with an open-beamed ceiling. Upon arrival, we were greeted very cordially and made to feel very welcome by the maitre d' and the waiters even though our Spanish is very minimal.  We ordered the house specialty-roast lamb for two and it was delicious. On the way out we were given a memento-a little key imprinted with the name of the restaurant. I highly recommend the Posada de la Villa for its cuisine, its service and its ambience.

title_review: Nice place but food a bit too simple
review_preview: This restaurant had really good reviews and we weren't disappointed on many points.  The atmosphere was calm with a nice bit of jazz playing in the background.  The waiter was attentive and helpful and the style above average.  The food overall was cooked and served...
review_full: This restaurant had really good reviews and we weren't disappointed on many points. The atmosphere was calm with a nice bit of jazz playing in the background. The waiter was attentive and helpful and the style above average. The food overall was cooked and served well but it was really very simple. We were here for lunch and had the Menu of the Day for 12 euros and I know you can only expect what you pay for but it is still a higher than average level restaurant so I don't see that as any excuse to offer something too simple. The alternative menu was quite extensive with some interesting looking items but not one single vegetarian option available and there was no offer to suggest an alternative for me so I had to go with fish again. We had soups to start, one was courgette, wild mint and spinach. It was well presented with a drizzle of oil and some garnish and tasted really good. I could taste all the flavours and it was not too salty which is often a real problem. My partner had the salmorejo - a traditional summer soup, served cold. It's a bit of a stretch to class a cold, wet November day as still summer though I have to say! We were served 3 different breads which were fresh, warm and really nice. Our mains were fish balls (hake) and Pollo Ganz (chicken in a pepper, onion and tomato sauce). The 3 fish balls were really nice and light and the chicken was OK but was cut into many small bite sized pieces whereas the chicken would have been much better for taste and texture if perhaps it had been cooked in one piece. The sauces were good but . . . . WHAT IS IT WITH THE SPANISH!!! Why doesn't any main dish get served as a balanced plate with some starchy element (potato, rice, pasta etc) and some vegetables! I just don't get it. How can you call a small plate of just meat and sauce a main meal? I often wonder if any chefs in Spain know that there are vegetables in the world. The dessert was a cheesecake which was well cooked, light and with a good texture but it lacked any real flavour. I would finish by saying that it was nice to eat food cooked nicely but the whole meal really was far too simple showing no real effort from the chef.

review_preview: My wife read the review on Facebook and told me we had to try it. So off we went. The hardest part about the restaurant is finding it because in Madrid every street seems to have a different name after each block. To our happy...
review_full: My wife read the review on Facebook and told me we had to try it. So off we went. The hardest part about the restaurant is finding it because in Madrid every street seems to have a different name after each block. To our happy surprise we found the restaurant finally and it was well worth the effort. She had the scallops and I had the duck. I was tempted to go for the lamb because as the waiter told me that it is a traditional Spanish dish, but he also advised me that their duck was better than anything in France. He wasn't kidding. We both agreed this might have been some the best dishes we'd ever had in our lives. Given how much traveling we do that's no small statement. In addition to the wonderful food the staff was really very kind given how little Spanish we speak. The play started getting busy at 9:30 and we were happy we arrived early. The bill was extremely reasonable given that we were in Madrid. I make unreserved recommendation of this restaurant.

review_preview: I was lucky enough to experience this restaurant as part of a recognition event and boy did those who arranged it get it right.   The service and the ambiance of this place were fantastic and the food outstanding.  As we were part of an organized...
review_full: I was lucky enough to experience this restaurant as part of a recognition event and boy did those who arranged it get it right. The service and the ambiance of this place were fantastic and the food outstanding. As we were part of an organized party our menu had been chosen for us however that was not an issue...We started off with a number of tasty tapas too numerous to remember (also not helped by the delicious wines we were served) and culminated in being served the famous house specialty of roast lamb. When I saw the waiter bringing out the earthenware dishes with the lamb in I thought we would probably be served two on a table of eight, but oh no...it was one between two and when placed on my plate I then proceeded to have the giggles because I couldn't get over the size of the portion. Saying that it is not served with veg just a green salad (which is more than enough). The lamb fell off the bone and has to have been one of the most delicious I have ever tasted.  The giving of a key to remember them by is a nice final touch to the visit,, As I have said I was lucky enough to go here as part of an organized party, but I would not hesitate to return here on my next trip to Madrid.

review_full: We went for the roast lamb. It was tender and excellent (their specialty), and would have been plenty for 3 people to share, or 4 if they didn't want large meat portions. We like vegetables and the lamb comes without accompaniments, so we ordered ratatouille and grilled veggies as our appetizers; both were excellent. We got an excellent bottle of rioja (2007 special reserve) for about 22 euros. The ambiance was warm and the service leisurely, yet attentive. We simply couldn't handle a dessert and coffee, but they brought us a small complementary dessert, a cookie and a chocolate, that were perfect. Our bill (including water, sliced potatoes, bread, olives, and everything above) was $100 euros; a splurge but not excessive for the lovely meal and service.

review_preview: I see that this restaurant has been criticised for not being 5 star dining, and therefore not worthy of a place in Madrid's Top 25 restaurants.Forget all that. No, it does not have waiters in starched linen, heroic prices, and faux friendly, formal service....
review_full: I see that this restaurant has been criticised for not being 5 star dining, and therefore not worthy of a place in Madrid's Top 25 restaurants. Forget all that. No, it does not have waiters in starched linen, heroic prices, and faux friendly, formal service. Instead, what it does have is much more valuable: quality and fresh ingredients prepared with care and passion, and delivered with friendly and helpful service. The result is beautiful food, creatively prepared and presented. We loved it. My only criticism is that we ordered too much, but that was our heart ruling our head. We would return in a heartbeat. This is a restaurant that deserves every success. If you like good food, go there. Bruno & Patrizia

title_review: If you were not here - you haven't been in Madrid
review_preview: Me and my wife were in this restaurant the first night in Madrid. We liked it so much, that we decided to have a dinner at our last night too. We don't speak Spanish, and our server, Javier was amazing and accommodating. I wanted to...
review_full: Me and my wife were in this restaurant the first night in Madrid. We liked it so much, that we decided to have a dinner at our last night too.  We don't speak Spanish, and our server, Javier was amazing and accommodating. I wanted to have the famous roasted lamb, but the dish listed in the menu was for two, Javier easily arranged it for one person. I looked at the wine list and asked him about my wine choice, so Javier recommended me another wine but in the same price range, without pushing it any higher. (very good advise). Now - the food. It should be said, that olives, bread and croquets are immediately at your table, even before you start ordering. For starters we had grilled asparagus, grilled "Padron" peppers and lamb sweetbreads.  The mains (and there were two nights): roasted lamb (WOW), grilled sea bass, and dear in sauce.  In addition, I asked for sliced tomatos to accompany meats, this was not in the menu, but the waiter brought it right away.  Resume - fantastic food, immaculate service, very cozy place. Definitely repeat when in Madrid. DEFINITELY.

title_review: When you're sick of fake "tapas" what a relief to find real food.
review_preview: Like a lot of people we just walked in here by accident wandering back form the park. We liked the look of the fixed price lunch menu so we sat down. The decor is beautiful, light, clean, graceful. We had three courses and a glass...
review_full: Like a lot of people we just walked in here by accident wandering back form the park. We liked the look of the fixed price lunch menu so we sat down. The decor is beautiful, light, clean, graceful. We had three courses and a glass of good red wine for 12.50 euros each. Within the constraints of this sort of deal it was very good food. It was our last day, and we'd already booked an evening meal otherwise I'd have gone for a siesta and returned. It really is a refreshing change from the majority of identikit tapas bars and formula restaurants that seem to be the norm in Madrid.

review_preview: My friend brought me to Ganz, as she had had several fabulous meals here. It was every bit as good as she promised. We had the burrata (made with buffalo milk, so I didn't have a reaction to it as I would had it been...
review_full: My friend brought me to Ganz, as she had had several fabulous meals here. It was every bit as good as she promised. We had the burrata (made with buffalo milk, so I didn't have a reaction to it as I would had it been cow dairy). It was delicious--served with a little bit of basil sorbet! We also had the roasted vegetables and the salmon tartare. Everything was great. Fernando was our server and he was also wonderful. He speaks English (which made ordering easy for me) and he totally understood and accommodated my food allergies (cow dairy, gluten, and soy). They even had a GF crackle bread. The decor is interesting and beautiful. The place is lively (totally full almost as soon as they opened--make a reservation), but not so loud you can't hear each other. I hope to go back on this trip, and certainly will the next time I'm in Madrid.

title_review: One of our best meals in Spain.
review_preview: This seemingly understated small restaurant on a side street near our hotel gave us one of the best meal experiences in Spain.  The food was filling and wonderful (after so many tapas restaurants where we had a hard time ordering the correct amount for 3...
review_full: This seemingly understated small restaurant on a side street near our hotel gave us one of the best meal experiences in Spain. The food was filling and wonderful (after so many tapas restaurants where we had a hard time ordering the correct amount for 3 hungry teenaged boys!) The burrata was out of this world and my beef cheeks filled with foie gras was my tastiest meal in Spain. With 5 of us eating every meal out for 10 days, we were trying to keep the price of restaurants reasonable, particularly since we had 2 picky eaters and one vegetarian along with us. I would highly recommend this restaurant and go there again next time I was in Madrid!

title_review: Creative presentation needs refinement in taste
review_preview: N40Â°24.678' W3Â°41.689' The chef is clearly a sculptor in his kitchen. Taste is king, but presentation is queen. The dishes are pieces of art, but unfortunately not a match for their taste. The slowly roasted lamb with couscous and curry sauce (â‚¬18,50) was good, but...
review_full: N40Â°24.678' W3Â°41.689' The chef is clearly a sculptor in his kitchen. Taste is king, but presentation is queen. The dishes are pieces of art, but unfortunately not a match for their taste. The slowly roasted lamb with couscous and curry sauce (â‚¬18,50) was good, but did not excite the taste buds. Not in the league of fine cuisine. Neither the grilled scallops on a bed of potato and cauliflower cream (â‚¬17) had delicate taste. Well cooked, but not with delicate taste and texture. Something was missing.  The restaurant itself is beautiful decorated, with a black and white tile floor and creative adjustable desk lamps on the walls. On this Saturday night in April 2017, the restaurant was not busy, mainly tourist and a few local guests. Overall, Ganz did not surprise us in the quality of their food. Get the taste on par with the presentation.

title_review: Very misleading name as NO TAPAS!
review_preview: You should know that there are actually two Tinto Y Tapas, the second and newer one located only 100 mores around the corner from the smaller original restaurant. I can't speak for the smaller original one as it was full when we found it (it...
review_full: You should know that there are actually two Tinto Y Tapas, the second and newer one located only 100 mores around the corner from the smaller original restaurant. I can't speak for the smaller original one as it was full when we found it (it only seats about 16 people approx) so they told us to go the other one which we were assured was the same. Ordered a glass of AlbariÃ±o (very nice) looked at the menu and left. They have absolutely no tapas on the menu which is bizarre given the name and the fact that they crop up regularly on the top ten list of great tapas in Madrid! The menu consists of mainly pizza, a few salads and empanadas, If I'd wanted pizza I'd have gone on holiday to Italy and I wasn't in the mood to eat lots of heavy empanadas. So I'm not criticizing the food in any way, just that it's very misleading and very disappointing if you've walked for 30 minutes to find it and be told that Tinto Y Tapas doesn't serve Tapas. I can only suggest that they change their name to Tinto Y Pizza, would be so much clearer!

review_preview: We came to this place specifically because other reviewers spoke highly of its breakfast offering. What a mistake!If you're looking for a hearty breakfast, this place is NOT it (no eggs, for example).If you're looking for a healthy breakfast, this place is also...
review_full: We came to this place specifically because other reviewers spoke highly of its breakfast offering. What a mistake! If you're looking for a hearty breakfast, this place is NOT it (no eggs, for example). If you're looking for a healthy breakfast, this place is also not it (fat yogurt, their only "cereal" options are various "fruit loops" style things; no oatmeal, no simple, sugarless flakes of any kind). Their main breakfast staple is the bread with tomato paste... except the bread wasn't there when we arrived shortly after they opened, and so we had to sit around the place waiting for their bread to be delivered. We do not advise this "highly rated" place, at least for breakfast, when you have much better options in even the usual tourist traps in the main squares. As a plus, the gentleman who served us was very nice, and their orange juice was good. Value for money was ok.

review_preview: We went to La Musa on our first night in Madrid as the restaurant was really close to our hotel. It is located in a neighbourhood with a lot of restaurants and bars and we choose this one because we saw from the window how...

It is located in a neighbourhood with a lot of restaurants and bars and we choose this one because we saw from the window how popular it was.  And indeed, it was the best choice we could made. I really loved it! After being in Spain for one week already and eating tapas day in day out, I was actually up for something different.... La Musa had surprised me with excellent fusion tapas inspired by different cuisines around the world! I highly recommend following tapas: - Peru-Lima y su ceviche  - Pan Bao  - Bomba - Notillas de mango It was so good that we came back again on our last night in Spain to finish a great week of holiday!

We sat next to one of their large street-facing windows which are open and give one the feeling of being outside but with the comfort of being indoors. I recommend ordering the mixed tapas selection for two. It includes starters, mains and a delicious dessert serving. The quality and presentation of the tapas is superb, honestly some of the best food I've ever tasted, not just tapas. The staff are friendly, their knowledge of each serving was helpful. The atmosphere is comfortable and the food is very good value for money. You could go to more expensive restaurants and not get the quality of food that La Musa serves! A gem of a tapas bar, I would highly recommend it.

review_preview: We went last Sunday to the Opera Brunch at the Westin Hotel and thoroughly enjoyed it. The buffet offers a wide choice of seafood, small little modern tapas and classics such as Paella. On top of that you get free-flow wines, beers and non-alcoholic beverages...
review_full: We went last Sunday to the Opera Brunch at the Westin Hotel and thoroughly enjoyed it. The buffet offers a wide choice of seafood, small little modern tapas and classics such as Paella. On top of that you get free-flow wines, beers and non-alcoholic beverages to your hearts contempt. The food over all was great and the glasses were never empty. However the highlight were the live opera singers who sang while walking around the diners. Really something different. At 78 Euros definitely worth the money. I hope to return again on my next Madrid visit. The only point of criticism would be that it starts rather late at 13.30h. I would prefer an 11.30h starts as it is done by other brunch places.

The food was also great, we tried the salmon tartare with mango (we were a bit sceptical at first because of the odd combination but it was actually great) and the vegetable lasagne. The food was fresh, deliciously made and neatly put. The prices are also reasonable considering the quality of the food and the fact that it's very close to Plaza Major. Briefly; it's the perfect place for someone who wants to have dinner in a cosy and warm restaurant! We'll definitely go back next time we're in Madrid.

There are very few restaurants in the world where you can get this simple provincial delicacy done well. Grab it!

review_full: You might be forgiven at first for thinking this is a bit of a tourist trap, and a bit too authentic to be true. But, although it is a popular tourist spot, it is also patronised by the locals, especially for Sunday lunch. A nice old fashioned atmosphere with plenty of professional looking staff. Service is good and the food, while not outstanding in any way, is traditional and very acceptable. Wines much as one might expect and many not too pricey. I have a problem with the seemingly universal habit of serving the food on cold plates. In Summer this may not matter, but in winter it means that the food gets cold far too quickly, and suffers as a result. More complaints please and maybe we can change habits!!

review_preview: I came down to this restaurant with my colleagues for a team dinner. We had the entire second floor to ourselves as we were a large number of people. I was very impressed with the decor of the restaurant. The rustic look somehow whetted our...
review_full: I came down to this restaurant with my colleagues for a team dinner. We had the entire second floor to ourselves as we were a large number of people. I was very impressed with the decor of the restaurant. The rustic look somehow whetted our appetite.  We had a long range of options. Appetizers were Bellota ham, Roasted peppers salad with Tuna, Andalusian fried squid, Scrambled eggs with shrimps and mushrooms, Homemade croquettes, Red sausage from Navarra, Posadero's onions and grilled vegetables.  The bellota ham, roasted peeppers salad, croquettes and grilled vegetables were the best.  For the main course, we had the option to choose from either Roast lamb in quarters cooked in a traditional oven, Fish hake casserole or Rice with vegetables. We were also served lettuce with onion salad and Sliced potatoes as a side dish. The roast lamb was tasty, the rice with vegetables and both starters were excellent. Fo dessert we had Bartolillos, fried milk cake and a pastry. The bartolillos were the best of the lot. Of course we had the standard white and red wines with mineral water or soda. We had coffee at the end of the meal with an option for tea as well. All food items were served in traditional vessels and the cutlery used was also beautiful. Both the food and eating experience were really great. We had a great time. We were also given a small key as a memento of our visit. I recommend the Posada de la Villa for a traditional Spanish dinner in a rustic ambience and traditional environment especiallyif you have a large group with you.

title_review: A very traditional Spanish restaurant, but nothing exciting.
review_preview: Had dinner here tonight.Classic Spanish dÃ©cor and very polite and attentive service.They have an asador, so the house speciality is cordero asado, so, as they say " A donde fueres, haz lo que vieres".As we have noticed with many establishments this year,...
review_full: Had dinner here tonight. Classic Spanish dÃ©cor and very polite and attentive service. They have an asador, so the house speciality is cordero asado, so, as they say " A donde fueres, haz lo que vieres". As we have noticed with many establishments this year, they padded the bill, which never happened on any of our many previous stays in Madrid over the years. The recommended house wine we ordered (a Marques de Riscal blanco ) was listed as 11,50, but when the bill arrived we were charged 16,00 euros. The other night we were charged for three coffees instead of 2, (not here) which is quite noticeable when there are only 2 of you! Perhaps it is just a sign of the times. It niggles, but it doesn't seem worth haggling over, we just simply adjust our tip accordingly! There was nothing wrong with the meal, but nothing to get excited about, either. One gazpacho, the lamb for 2 (42,00) water, wine, 2 sorbets (6,80 each) and coffee came to 94,00 euros. It ticked the box of eating in a traditional Spanish posada. I have discovered some much more interesting and less advertised places this year, such as La Mi Venta, where I had one of the best meals of all my trips to Madrid so far!

review_preview: We ended up here by chance, as our intended destination was closed for renovation. First impressions may be a little confusing: is this a typical traditional Spanish restaurant or a tourist trap?  Given that it is located in the heart of the restaurant area, it...
review_full: We ended up here by chance, as our intended destination was closed for renovation. First impressions may be a little confusing: is this a typical traditional Spanish restaurant or a tourist trap? Given that it is located in the heart of the restaurant area, it could be either. But in the end we gave it the benefit of the doubt and enjoyed a good meal, in traditional style. All very typical stuff, but one or two tempting excitements: snails in a delicious sauce, arroz with rabbit. Good fish dishes. All served in a place with a good traditional atmosphere, and cheerful, if also traditional service. Plenty of red wines to choose from, but fewer interesting whites, almost all Spanish. That's normal Madrid. Worth a visit, and at â‚¬150 for three people, three courses and a bottle of wine, good value.

review_preview: Booked our 9PM reservation at this popular restaurant on-line through the link here on Tripadvisor before we left for our trip. 9PM in the US would be considered late, but in Madrid it is very early. This was our 1st night in Madrid, having arrived...
review_full: Booked our 9PM reservation at this popular restaurant on-line through the link here on Tripadvisor before we left for our trip. 9PM in the US would be considered late, but in Madrid it is very early. This was our 1st night in Madrid, having arrived from NY early that AM, so I thought a reservation on the "earlier" side (Madrid definition of "earlier") would be best. Next time, I would do 10 or 11PM. There was only a few other tables of diners when we arrived, but by the time we left most of the tables were filled. The ambiance is wonderful and warm, even from the outside, with a feeling of old Madrid and tradition and aromas pulling you in. We were welcomed warmly and seated at a table next to an adorable old hearth oven. The specialty here is roast suckling lamb which my husband and I shared - It was outstanding. We also had the baked clams appetizer which came with 12 clams and would have been plenty for four people, and the grilled asparagus, and ordered bottle of the house red wine, which was excellent. I thought the service was superb. This was a perfect choice for our first night in Madrid.

Lots of great regional wines and a knowledgeable staff. It is very affordable at well. We had a great time, and look forward to coming back during our next visit to Madrid. One word of warning. The portions are pretty large for "tapas." Dishes are really made to be like 2 per person rather than the typical 3-5 for tapas. Just a warning since we ordered way too much food. Also, if I had to skip anything, it would probably be the pizza. The pizza was good, but a little too typical compared to the rest of the amazing menu. We didn't have an open faced sandwich but looked super tasty.

title_review: What a great way to spend a Sunday afternoon!
review_preview: My partner booked this as a treat a few days beforehand because I like a bit of opera and the Palace does a Sunday 'brunch and opera' event in the Rotonda. On the face of it, its a little pricey but it was worth every...
review_full: My partner booked this as a treat a few days beforehand because I like a bit of opera and the Palace does a Sunday 'brunch and opera' event in the Rotonda. On the face of it, its a little pricey but it was worth every penny! The setting is wonderful, under the stained glass, domed ceiling. The buffet is stupendous with loads of choice and such things as lobster, langoustines, scallops, foie and partridge among the things on offer. The real gems are in the canapes, fish and seafood sections! We were offered champagne on arrival and I suspect you could have drunk as much as you wanted as the staff were always offering to refill our glasses as well as wine and then tea or coffee to follow. To cap it all, a soprano and tenor accompanied on piano entertain you as you eat! Lots of popular numbers and some less well known. They ended with Verdi's Brindisi from 'Traviata' and the waiters refilled our glasses so that the singers could come and 'clink' every one. Service was 'formal' but not at all stuffy. We dressed up a little but 'smart casual' was all that was required. It was terrific fun and a real highlight of the holiday!

title_review: Step Back in Time and Enjoy
review_preview: This hotel restaurant is a focal point of the Westin Palace Madrid. Beautifully refurbished to the period when the hotel was built. The glass dome with coloured glass and a beautiful crystal chandelier draws you towards the central area where breakfast is served, lunch and...
review_full: This hotel restaurant is a focal point of the Westin Palace Madrid. Beautifully refurbished to the period when the hotel was built. The glass dome with coloured glass and a beautiful crystal chandelier draws you towards the central area where breakfast is served, lunch and afternoon drinks follow with a la carte dining at night. You were spoilt for choice at the breakfast buffet and the night menu was quite reasonable in choice. The meals were presented with flair in the fine dining vain. The wine list was presented by ipad in categories and reasonably extensive for choice. The service at breakfast and evening meals was prompt, friendly and attentive. We would definitely return again for another meal.

review_preview: Got to this restaurant thru Trip Adviser recommendation. As per most of the reviewers commented, it is worth making a visit, though it is slightly off the main down town. If you followed the "Free Walking Tour", it is within the walking route.  The restaurant...
review_full: Got to this restaurant thru Trip Adviser recommendation. As per most of the reviewers commented, it is worth making a visit, though it is slightly off the main down town. If you followed the "Free Walking Tour", it is within the walking route. The restaurant specialty is their Crispy lamb, it is not hard crispy roasted as I expected. To put it in Chinese cooking, this is a bit like "braise", a bit wet but not gravy. Portion is just good probably for two adult but I have 3 ladies with smaller diet is still good portion. Very interesting dish and pair it with its house wine is excellent! The restaurant itself is big but not crowded nor rowdy, decoration is warm and traditional with a big stone grill oven, like an Indian Tandoori Oven that make the place very special. Staffs are friendly and helpful even though they cannot speak very fluent English but had made some effort to recommend good food. As for the price, it is high of Spanish standard.

title_review: Excellent dome feature - Good hotel dining!
review_preview: We have had breakfast and dinner at this venue and the standout feature is the glass dome covering the dining area, which is a great feature and creates an enjoyable ambience.Although the breakfast was very good this rating is for our dining experience.Firstly,...
review_full: We have had breakfast and dinner at this venue and the standout feature is the glass dome covering the dining area, which is a great feature and creates an enjoyable ambience. Although the breakfast was very good this rating is for our dining experience. Firstly, we had a problem in that although we had made a phone booking there was no record of our call upon arrival. When making the booking our details had to be repeated, for each aspect, because of the lack of understanding of English by the restaurant receptionist , and at the time, we felt there could be problems, which happened! Fortunately, there was one remaining table unallocated for our 7pm arrival. Once seated there seemed to be an abundance of staff scurrying about but we received little attention until we asked to see a wine list.  A combination of patrons, some having evening drinks and some seated for fine dining , possibly is not a good mix for service attention in the same area? Upon asking to be served we were attended by Jorge, who provided a high level of service and good advice on menu choice and the wine list. The menu is extensive , and not unexpected for a in hotel fine dining restaurant. To start, we had a chefs special appetiser of a slice of banana with jelly crystals, which to us was not appetising and should be passed! For entrees we chose the smoked sardines and soup . Both meals were well presented and the broccoli soup quite hot. Our main courses were the salmon and a Caesar salad which was a delicate serving, as a listed starter meal, which was to our liking. The salmon was cooked, as Jorge suggested, being a little rare inside. This meal, relative to the other seafood dishes , was well priced and good value.  The wine list, on an iPad, provided good choices but at hotel prices. We selected a Spanish Verdello white wine which was enjoyable. Overall, this venue started out as another hotel average dining experience, but thanks to Jorge, was turned around into a pleasant evening.

review_preview: We visited Rollerie for Sunday brunch and it was amazing, definitely one of the best such places in the center of Madrid.The decoration inside is lovely, but if the weather is good, you can sit at a table outside and enjoy the lovely alley,...
review_full: We visited Rollerie for Sunday brunch and it was amazing, definitely one of the best such places in the center of Madrid. The decoration inside is lovely, but if the weather is good, you can sit at a table outside and enjoy the lovely alley, very close to the Plazuela de San Gines. We ordered an english breakfast (which was OK) and the Brunch Iberico, which was delicious. At 17.50 Euro it is bit pricey, but definitely worth it because the ingredients are of the highest quality and you can eat so many things. It has a spanish potato omellete (Tortilla de patatas), a great selection of jamÃ³n ibÃ©rico (amazing!), a selection of gourmet breads accompanied by tomato emulsion (breads were fresh, warm and served with butter) and, for desert, churros with hot chocolate. Finally, the coffee was very good (not so usual for Madrid cafes!). Our waitress was super attentive and polite, and her english was quite good, too! Overall, definitely recommended!

Well L'artisan seems to have nailed fusing both of these worlds, and offers some of the best dishes i've had in Spain for a while now. The butterfish is simply out of this world. review_preview: We go to Madrid a lot, so when a guidebook said that Casa Paco was a must visit, we tried it. A mistake. We got there early for lunch. The restaurant is tucked behind an ancient bar. They claim to specialize in meats, but they...
review_full: We go to Madrid a lot, so when a guidebook said that Casa Paco was a must visit, we tried it. A mistake.  We got there early for lunch. The restaurant is tucked behind an ancient bar. They claim to specialize in meats, but they don't have either cochinillo or cordero asado, even though these are Castillian specialties.  I had a friend morcilla which was totally overcooked. My wife had a greasy grilled vegetable appetizer (which was cooked on a flat top, not a grill. ) Lunch was a total disappointment, but the bill was a problem.  I can't eat gluten, so we only got one bread, but they charged for two. When I complained, they refused to fix the bill, saying the bread charge was essentially a service charge. Seriously?  We'll never go back.

title_review: Not worth the rating it's got!
review_preview: Really couldn't work out how this place gets such a high rating.  We went here after not getting into 2 others (Algarabia and La Candela Resto - and this was on a Tuesday night!)The menu looked a bit sparse and we decided against the...
review_full: Really couldn't work out how this place gets such a high rating. We went here after not getting into 2 others (Algarabia and La Candela Resto - and this was on a Tuesday night!) The menu looked a bit sparse and we decided against the "starters" since we weren't sure whether they were actually starters or tapas. If the latter, they were a bit expensive, ranging from 10 euros up to 16. If they were starters then they looked rather boring (and expensive). We weren't offered a wine list, and when we asked for one there was only wine on it. No beer or coffee or shorts etc. When we ordered the mains (venison and sea bass) we asked what I think was the head waiter whether there was enough veg/spuds etc. on the plate or whether need to order extra - although there was actually only spuds done three ways (roast, chipped, boiled). He said there was enough on the plate so we went with it. When they came it was a joke! The venison came with a small spud and a slice (yes, one slice) of carrot and some thing green. The sea bass came with some green salad and half a bigger spud. Needless to say we ordered some more! I asked for chipped potatoes. The waiter came back with tomato ketchup. Bizarre. When we asked again (a bit louder, obviously . . we're Brits, after all) he said "ah yes, pepper!" We gave up, asked for the menu and pointed to the roast potatoes Instead. When they came, they were sliced and boiled and in a buttery sauce. Your guess is probably as good as mine what the chipped ones were like! We actually looked around for the hidden cameras by this point. Perhaps we missed the point of the place. It was supposed to be like some old trad place but we reckoned it was too big, expensive, with crappy service and there's loads better restaurants around the city centre if you look and book.

We stayed in Madrid for 4 nights, and ended up going there every day to see friendly faces to practice our (very poor) Spanish, and relax after a day of exploring. Visiting this place really gave us the feeling of travelling like a local. I only say that I don't want to write about this place, as it's so great don't want it to be overrun by travelers, but so good that it's worth passing on as a gem. Enjoy!

title_review: The owner hasn't got a clue ...
review_preview: The owner hasn't got a clue how good this place is!!!! On our arrival he was a bag of nerves and genuinely couldn't understand why a couple from London had picked his restaurant above others in the area. It was so refreshing to see someone...
review_full: The owner hasn't got a clue how good this place is!!!! On our arrival he was a bag of nerves and genuinely couldn't understand why a couple from London had picked his restaurant above others in the area. It was so refreshing to see someone genuinely shocked by our glowing feedback.  The space is incredibly unique. Both floors are quite different but there's a sense of cool that runs throughout. The artwork that litters the exposed brick walls and the industrial style lighting makes for a great setting.  The food is outstanding. Some French. Some Japanese. All fantastic.  The staff literally cannot do enough for you. You can tell there's a determination within the team to make their new venture work and they're doing just that.  The bar has a great selection of spirits and the cocktails are freshly made and delicious. The passion fruit Mojitos were in full flow that's for sure. title_review: Curious place, original food, good service
review_preview: This is not fusion cuisine as some reviewers say. There's a very definite distinction between what's contemporary French and what's traditional Japanese, but you can mix'n 'match. There 6 French and 6 Japanese starters; almost the same number and ratio of mains but all the...
review_full: This is not fusion cuisine as some reviewers say. There's a very definite distinction between what's contemporary French and what's traditional Japanese, but you can mix'n 'match. There 6 French and 6 Japanese starters; almost the same number and ratio of mains but all the desserts are naturally French... The place is curious. We ate on the ground floor in a sort of tunnel which reminded me of a railway carriage with an open kitchen at the end which brings you into natural contact with the chef. Apparently there is also a dining room in the basement. The menu is unusual and attractive. We shared the house roll sushi as a starter and for mains had one French and one Japanese dish: pez limÃ³n (amberjack apparently in English) and udon noodles. plus two different and delicious desserts. It was all very good. TIP: Try the Japanese mojito with sake, midori (melon liqueur), lime, mint, sugar and fresh ginger. The house wine by the glass is also good value.

review_preview: La Tavernetta serves up the scintilating savors of Sicily and Sardinia in the centre of Spain.  (OK, make that Madrid.) The restaurant is small, basic but decent.  The basement has a more intimate atmosphere probably better suited to small groups of friends, families etc.  Ground...
review_full: La Tavernetta serves up the scintilating savors of Sicily and Sardinia in the centre of Spain. (OK, make that Madrid.) The restaurant is small, basic but decent. The basement has a more intimate atmosphere probably better suited to small groups of friends, families etc. Ground floor has mostly tables for two which are shoe-horned in but this hardly matters once you start eating.  The food is superb. I recommend the pasta with soft-shelled crab - utterly delicious and something hard to resist with each return visit. But everything we have eaten here has been superb, from the fragrant leg of lamb scented with herbs and braised (in wine?) to the wonderful caponata. Servings are quite generous and prices are very moderate for this quality and quantity. Great lunchtime menu deals make it a very affordable option for mid-week lunches too. Service is friendly and attentive. The restaurant seems to be open most of the day so, although a booking is probably advisable, if you can be flexible about the time, it's likely they'll be able to fit you in. Go there once and you'll find yourself going back regularly when you fancy something a bit different. Far and away the best Italian I have tried in Madrid.

review_full: The food was actually very good, but when we asked for the bill the waiter came and told us that we had to pay 43â‚¬. This sounded weird to us because we were quite sure that we would have had to pay less (we were 4, a friend of us hadnâ€™t even ordered anything to eat and we had split some dishes). Then the waiter told us that we could have paid 3 euros less if we wanted (we only wanted the bill to check it ). We asked for the receipt because we simply wanted to see what had made the price higher than expected and when the waiter gave it to us we eventually found out that the price was actually 10 euros less than what he had told us. Not a big deal, but it was quite weird that when the waiter gave us the difference he didnâ€™t apologize for the mistake (that could have happened), but made fun of us with another client in Spanish thinking that we couldnâ€™t understand him (only because we asked for a normal bill and didnâ€™t want to pay anything on an oral basis )!  Good food, but we felt judged only because we wanted to have a normal receipt (I donâ€™t want to think that they wanted to trick us only because we were tourists ).

review_preview: I went with a friend on a Saturday morning. When we arrived there was a queue but it did not take long at all o be seated, the staff were very efficient.The menu was much bigger than the one I had seen online which...
review_full: I went with a friend on a Saturday morning. When we arrived there was a queue but it did not take long at all o be seated, the staff were very efficient. The menu was much bigger than the one I had seen online which was great because I had previously thought my choices limited to breakfast options. They had many lunch and dinner choices. My friend and I both ordered Brunch plates and they were HUGE. My friend's dish (Iberian Brunch) came with 'breads' and she ended up with three or four mini baguettes which were warm too. My meal was equally as impressive and they also bought me extra bread which wasn't featured on the menu. I have a big appetite and I was honestly full for hours after finishing this. Normally I wouldn't pay â‚¬17 for a Brunch but the quantity of food and the fact it includes both orange juice and a coffee/tea honestly has me planning my next trip. What I Would say is that although they do offer the odd vegan pastry this seems to be more of a tokenistic gesture than something actually worthy of. I think adding the option to swap eggs for tofu scramble or greek yogurt for soya yogurt or something like that would make a big difference :)

review_full: This restaurant met all expectations in terms of food, atmosphere and service. The menu offered an eclectic choice of either European or Japanese food, but in both ranges tended to the nouveau (i.e. Not heavy) end of the spectrum. The goats cheese salad with melon was delicious, as, too was the Japanese roll of tuna, salmon with guacamole side sauce. For mains, we had oven roasted butterfish, delicately cooked and served with fresh ginger and steamed rice, then the udon noodles which were in the fusion category with a soy sauce, but also sautÃ©ed ?red onions thinly sliced and a hint of capsicum. Throw in a couple of glasses of Spanish champagne, an entirely charming and attentive waiter and an elegant cellar eating space and we had a terrific evening. Highly recommended!

review_preview: It's difficult to not be disappointed after reading such glowing reviews but we really were impressed by the quality food and fantastic service last night. With a rambunctious two year old in tow, we decided to sit next to the kitchen. This made it convenient...
review_full: It's difficult to not be disappointed after reading such glowing reviews but we really were impressed by the quality food and fantastic service last night.  With a rambunctious two year old in tow, we decided to sit next to the kitchen. This made it convenient to give our compliments to the chefs as we were leaving. (And surely they saw our immensely satisfied faces as we devoured the feast.)  We started with the tempura sardines (our daughter ate most of them) and the avocado salad with apple. (More avocado please!! Oh so delicious!!) We continued with the best udon I've ever had (although I know the goal of this restaurant isn't fusion, I feel like this traditional udon has fused with genius and become multicultural, modern and fantastic.)  The chirashi we ate was lovely, my husband is still wishing he could prepare rice like that. And we wondered the entire way home what made the mashed potatoes with the beef so incredibly fabulous. The beef itself was a masterpiece. The two desserts we had were decadent. So the conversation has turned now to what we will order on our next visit. We can't wait! Thank you for a memorable meal!

review_full: My boyfriend and I ate here in August. We went for the 30 euro deal which is for two people. They did not provide an English menu but the waiter translated as much as he could and obviously we did not mind anyway!  The deal includes some olives to begin. We were then given bread which we paid extra for but did not mind as it was needed. We then got 4 cold tapas (salmon was amazing). Next 4 hot tapas came all of which were great. Lastly 3 dessert tapas came and they were all very good (a fruity type of mousse, chocolate brownie, and cheesecake). It's very nice inside and service was good and not slow. We went at 8 on a Saturday night without booking and we were seated right away. It became busy by the time we left.  We also had a jug of sangria which was nice and quite cheap (I think about 13 euros) - it was a massive jug. Overall the food was delicious and excellent for the price! Would definitely go again.

review_preview: A friend living in Madrid came with my friend and I and ordered the breakfast called Andaluz con Jamon Serrano. I thought I would do the same. Oh my goodness!!! 2 pieces of toasted bread arrived, along with 2 slices of jamon Serrano and a...
review_full: A friend living in Madrid came with my friend and I and ordered the breakfast called Andaluz con Jamon Serrano. I thought I would do the same. Oh my goodness!!!  2 pieces of toasted bread arrived, along with 2 slices of jamon Serrano and a wonderful tomato sauce (I tried to get the recipe, but shhhhh, was told it was a secret). Wow wow wow. I had 3 times the same breakfast, that's how much I loved it. Ok, not on the same day :-).  The funny thing is, instead of ordering tea or coffee, I thought I should be more original and ordered a chocolate. Well, a sumptuous thick chocolate made my day! It's the chocolate you typically get with churros; the chocolate itself resembles the Italian ciobar, for those familiar with it? So if you enjoy thick chocolate, brilliant, otherwise, if you want the regular hot chocolate, you have to ask for a Nesquick chocolate. Also, lots of place offer a natural zumo de naranja, a natural orange juice. Wait for the best: toasts, jamon and tomato (plus tea or coffee or nesquick chocolate) for 3.50euros. Cheers!

review_preview: After reading the previous great critics, my expectations were high for this place. First of all, the food: We had the house maki roll (x2), the reblochon omelette, the sardinas tempura and the chirasi. The maki roll was very original and with a good balance...
review_full: After reading the previous great critics, my expectations were high for this place.  First of all, the food: We had the house maki roll (x2), the reblochon omelette, the sardinas tempura and the chirasi. The maki roll was very original and with a good balance of flavours. The reblochon omelette was also very nice and perfectly done. We didnt love the Chirasi because the tuna and the white fish were nothing special. The prawns were quite good and the salmon also. The last dish, the tempura sardines, they recommended it as the best dish they had. I found this dish quite terrible: the tempura was thick and oily and the fish inside was lacking the texture of fresh fish. We also found that flavours did not match. I honestly cannot understand how they consider this their best dish. Regading the service, they were very nice and helpful but a bit long, given that they only had 2 tables that night. We took more than 2 hours to eat these 4 dishes with no dessert. Also, we did not love the music, it was too much of a mix of african, spanish and oriental songs (I think) which did not go that much together and was annoying at some points. I think the price is fair, but not a bargain like previous reviewers stated: we had 5 dishes (only one main), two beers, some wine and a coffee and we paid 65 â‚¬. Also, note that it is not fusion of french and japanese, but the menu is divided between japanese dishes and french dishes.

review_preview: The  place is really nice and the staff is friendly. But, if you're searching for a typical Madrid's spirit, maybe this isn't the right ambiance. La Musa is more a like bobo-hipster, as you'd find in Paris.The decoration is nice and cosy. The "bombas"...
review_full: The place is really nice and the staff is friendly. But, if you're searching for a typical Madrid's spirit, maybe this isn't the right ambiance. La Musa is more a like bobo-hipster, as you'd find in Paris. The decoration is nice and cosy.  The "bombas" (potato&meat) are really good, but the chicken "na brasa" (bbq/smoked) is not amazing, but still good. The sangria is average, but the mojito is pretty good. The serving sizes may be too small for some people, but with 4 tapas + dessert we were not hungry in the end.

Also enjoyed the dessert tasting menu and sangria! Great vibe and fast and courteous service.

review_preview: We have recently been to La Rollerie for a breakfast with the family. The place is quite beautifully decorated with lots of flowers and a very French touch. The menu is the same for breakfast, brunch or lunch and includes many choices of breakfast, toasts,...
review_full: We have recently been to La Rollerie for a breakfast with the family. The place is quite beautifully decorated with lots of flowers and a very French touch. The menu is the same for breakfast, brunch or lunch and includes many choices of breakfast, toasts, salads, soups, pasta, appetizers, burgers and specialties. We chose the breakfast for 2 plus some other things. The quantity of pastry is more than enough. The coffee was good, the orange juice regular and the tomato for the bread was weird as minimum. The price for the full breakfast was more than it should be, it is an expensive place. The service was quite bad, we had call the waiter in several occasions and he ignored us or forgot about us.  In essence, it i a trendy place, another example of focusing on the aesthetics rather than service and quality of products. Some of the food was quite good, other was pretty average at best. Price is very high, service is bad-regular, decoration is its main bet. Will I repeat? Probably some day to see how lunch goes.

review_preview: Dishes are on the culinary side. Some dishes were a bit off balance (e.g. too much mustard or wasabi in the avocado and green apple salad), but don't take this as a serious. On the other hand, you're getting maximum value for money here. We...
review_full: Dishes are on the culinary side. Some dishes were a bit off balance (e.g. too much mustard or wasabi in the avocado and green apple salad), but don't take this as a serious. On the other hand, you're getting maximum value for money here. We were two and shared everything in good Spanish style. We had tempura sardines as a first starter. Do note that you get tempura fish as part of the appetizers of the house. The sardines are in big what the appetizers are in small. Other appetizers were olives (who were delicous by the way!) Avocado and green apple salad with mustard sauce was our second starter. As said, a bit too much mustard in there.But overall very tasty and very well presented. As main dish we took the chicken and the sting ray. Both were excellent. We took a house wine that was simple and very fair priced (10 euro botttle) All in a, we paid 56 euro for all this plus water and gin tonic. The place was only half full when we went, mostly tourists. Although food was very good quality and prices were really reasonable for what you get. Staff is very friendly Would go there again.

review_preview: I have had a chance to visit L'Artisan a couple of times over the last three months and have been pleasantly surprised by the originality, quality  and thoughtfulness of the dishes. This is not your typical fusion restaurant, rather it presents elements of French and...
review_full: I have had a chance to visit L'Artisan a couple of times over the last three months and have been pleasantly surprised by the originality, quality and thoughtfulness of the dishes. This is not your typical fusion restaurant, rather it presents elements of French and Japanese cuisines separately but it in such a way that they complement each other in such to create a harmonious and cohesive whole. I strongly recommend the Ceviche with Wakame, House Roll, Duck Magret, Roasted miso-marinated Butterfish, and Pan-seared Ray with seasonal greens and lardons. The Menu changes regularly, but always for the better. It's a different take on the Nikkei trend at a more reasonable price point that definitely warrants a visit. Make sure to book a table downstairs!

First impression is definitely 5 green dots. Can't wait to try out the lunch menu one day.

title_review: Madrid's Best kept Secret...not any more......go downstairs
review_preview: Wow, Wow, Wow. We tried hard to find a restaurant in Madrid that would satisfy us and this one tops all of them. Alba was our waitress and she was very attentive and fun. She made the night before even starting to dine. When you...
review_full: Wow, Wow, Wow. We tried hard to find a restaurant in Madrid that would satisfy us and this one tops all of them. Alba was our waitress and she was very attentive and fun. She made the night before even starting to dine. When you first look into L'Artisan it doesn't give you the whole picture as all you see is a bar an a few chairs. The dinning room is downstairs and a very inviting area to dine. We were looking for a nice seafood dish and maybe even some sushi. We had a terrible experience the night before with a "Seafood" restaurant not too far away from this one...bigger and glitter is not always better that's for sure. Our evening consisted of the following perfectly made dishes. We both had the Green apple salad with avocado, and then Avocado and Salmon tartar with a touch of dill, yummy. I was up for some sushi so I had the House roll which had tuna, salmon, wild sea bass and guacamole, the guacamole was a really unexpected touch on the sushi. For our main dishes we both picked the same dish which was the Oven Roasted Butterfish marinated in Saikyo Miso. If you don't go here you are missing a really great dinning experience.

The pancakes that we were ordered were all sweet pancakes. They looked good when they arrived but were smothered in sauces. I have a sweet tooth but this was too sweet for me. One of the children had chocolate sauce, the other toffee sauce which they both left a lot of as again way too much was put into and onto the pancakes. Unfortunately, we were disappointed with this establishment and would not recommend going out of your way to visit.

review_preview: Two days ago I found myself with some time to kill and feeling hungry.  I was in Colon (along Calle Genova) which I thought I knew very well until I stumbled across this great little crepe restaurant.  The atmosphere was contemporary but friendly and the...
review_full: Two days ago I found myself with some time to kill and feeling hungry. I was in Colon (along Calle Genova) which I thought I knew very well until I stumbled across this great little crepe restaurant. The atmosphere was contemporary but friendly and the two guys working there (Portuguese Manager and Spanish Chef) were both really friendly and professional too. Both spoke English as well as Spanish and I discovered that the owner of this restaurant is British and that he has a chain of restaurants but that this is their first in Madrid and has been open for 3 months now (probably why I hadnÂ´t noticed it before!!!). After looking at their extensive menu (in Spanish and English) I ordered "La Prep" (a savoury pancake with cheese, ham (English style), and egg) and I had it with extra tuna. The ingredients were fresh and generous and the pancake was a great size enough to fill me up completely but without being overwhelming. I also asked for a drink they didnÂ´t have but they told me I could chose from the fridge and so I chose apple juice. I was later told that they normally offer this to children who come in as it helps offer them something they (and parents!) like. They were also very happy for me to take the pancake that I couldnÂ´t finish in the restaurant away with me and packed it in a nice plastic container for me as a take-away. In summary, Prep La Crepe is a lovely cafe style restaurant with friendly and family orientated attentive staff who serve great food and make you feel at home as you enjoy your meal. The price was also reasonable and was fair for the large portion I received. I would thoroughly recommend this little restaurant and will definitely be going back there myself very soon!

title_review: Better than a 4, not quite a 5
review_preview: Great small place on a side street.La Musa doesn't look like much from the outside.  Inside, the high-top tables that ring the perimeter all have 'Reserved' on them as clearly this place is known to be tasty.And that was the case.  Over about...
review_full: Great small place on a side street. La Musa doesn't look like much from the outside. Inside, the high-top tables that ring the perimeter all have 'Reserved' on them as clearly this place is known to be tasty. And that was the case. Over about 75 minutes we sampled many of the Tapas on the menu.  Highlights: Carrileras Con Setas - this mushroom 'shepherds pie' dish served with crusty bread had my 12 year old son eating something he would never touch at home. The Bomba. Looks like a scotch egg. Instead it is a deep friend potato and meat thing. Amazing. Pan Bao. Basically a pork bun but with Shrimp inside presented like a taco. Nuggets. Chicken Nuggets for your kids. The Guacamole is 'self-pestled' The Hummus is so-so. The Empanadillas Japonesa are chicken potstickers. Didn't have the noodles but the rest of the table liked them. Great staff. Great value. Shame that I told you about this place. but it deserves the kudos.

review_preview: Great classical asador with superb service. Cordero Asado is the specialty. Did not see any service issues as mentioned earlier. On the contrary, one of the most professional wait staff and friendly service I've seen in 35 years of living and visiting Madrid. Had the...
review_full: Great classical asador with superb service. Cordero Asado is the specialty. Did not see any service issues as mentioned earlier. On the contrary, one of the most professional wait staff and friendly service I've seen in 35 years of living and visiting Madrid. Had the Cordero Asado for lunch, very delicious and plentiful. The wine list is also very good in regional selections. This is not a budget place and quite pricey and expected for traditional restaurants of this caliber, it matches the price range of similar locations in Madrid. So, no big surprises if you understand this, if it's your very first time to enjoy this Spanish cuisine. Very nice old rustic atmosphere for a reason, no modernization required as some complainers persist. Don't expect a perfect meal in these traditional restaurants. It's exceptional for being in a tourist location. So, of course the quality and prices change through the decades. So, DON'T try to relive old memories of the this place. Madrid has changed so much in the last 30 years. Just enjoy for today.

review_preview: Lâ€™Artisan Furansu Kitchen is an unexpected find in the culinary landscape of Madrid, as it reaches an intersection between Japanese cooking techniques and contemporary French dishes. With a mission to showcase the harmonious relationship between the two cuisines, Lâ€™artisan Furansu Kitchen creates a unique menu...
review_full: Lâ€™Artisan Furansu Kitchen is an unexpected find in the culinary landscape of Madrid, as it reaches an intersection between Japanese cooking techniques and contemporary French dishes. With a mission to showcase the harmonious relationship between the two cuisines, Lâ€™artisan Furansu Kitchen creates a unique menu each weekday, relative to the goods available in the market. This ensures each dish is always at its freshest and crafted using the finest ingredients possible.  With three different dining areas to choose from, including the intimate castiza for date nights, and the bar area which serves European and Japanese cocktails and libations, my friend and I opted for the room which allowed us to see our food being prepared in the kitchen. Exciting to watch the chefâ€™s in action as they prepared our lunch, and our server was helpful in explaining the menu and the dining options. We shared a starter of mackerel tartare, with green onion, ginger and aubergine caviar. I hadnâ€™t tasted anything like this before, and it was a great way to set the tone of our lunch. The subtle flavors of ginger and green onion perfectly reflected the Japanese influence. The soft pork belly was slow cooked for 12 hours, and the sweet soy sauce complimented the tender meat.  My friend ordered the oven-roasted butterfish, marinated in saikyo miso and she couldnâ€™t stop raving about it. I enjoyed a rack of lamb served with yucca fritters. The yucca fritters were something completely new and exciting, and a great take on a root vegetable. The lamb was meaty, juicy, and just right.  Dessert included rhubarb crumble with custard cream and green tea ice cream with mochi and dorayaki. We couldnâ€™t decide which we liked better, because both were so delicious, so we just shared them and ate both!  Lâ€™artisan Furansu Kitchen is not culinary fusion, but a symphony of flavors from two important cuisines.

review_preview: After passing by this place many times, I never really bothered to try it out because it didnâ€™t look particularly remarkable and Sushi Shop next door always seemed like the better option. Boy, was I wrong. After reading the many positive reviews Prep La Crepe...
review_full: After passing by this place many times, I never really bothered to try it out because it didnâ€™t look particularly remarkable and Sushi Shop next door always seemed like the better option. Boy, was I wrong. After reading the many positive reviews Prep La Crepe had on different websites, I finally decided to try it out and was not disappointed. From the unpretentious dÃ©cor to the extremely welcoming and friendly staff (who knew this could be possible in Madrid, and on Calle Genova of all places?) the atmosphere is extremely positive and invites you to relax and enjoy yourself. As if that wasnâ€™t enough, the food is pretty great and the prices are very reasonable. Though the â€œmenu del diaâ€ will always give you the better deal anywhere you go, fear not if you come here for dinner or during the weekend. If you order a small salad as well as a crepe and a drink, then the price will be practically the same and the experience will be just as lovely. Although my personal experience was probably perfect due to a combination of factors, I would definitely like to thank the staff for being so professional and for politely answering every single question and request from their customers, no matter how silly or random these were (from swapping cold water for room temperature water to asking how many stairs there are to the bathroom). Who knows? Maybe the trend of having both great food and great service in a single place will actually catch on and Madrid will become just a little more pleasant.

review_preview: Major gem amongst a lot of great food in Madrid. My friend and I could not stop raving over the food during the entire meal at L'Artisan. We knew a french Japanese spot was an odd choice but we were feeling like something different after...
review_full: Major gem amongst a lot of great food in Madrid. My friend and I could not stop raving over the food during the entire meal at L'Artisan. We knew a french Japanese spot was an odd choice but we were feeling like something different after several days of tapas. Had I known how spectacular our experience was to be, we would have planned more meals here. The sav blanc (offered by the glass) was exquisite... Frankly one of the best I've ever had. We shared the house roll, avocado-Apple salad and butterfish and were blown away with every course. Downstairs provides a cute and cozy, cave-like setting, perfect for an intimate evening with a close friend or partner. To top it off the service was perfect. Muchas gracias!!

review_full: I came here with my boyfriend whilst on holiday in Madrid as it was recommended by the lonely planet guide book and was exceptionally surprised. We didn't speak much spanish and they unfortunately didn't have an English menu but neither of us are fussy so we just decided to try the tasting menu for 30 euros for the 2 of us. The food was exceptional, and most of the staff could speak very good English and were able to explain what each of the dishes were and guide us how to eat it (ie one dish was an avocado shrimp cocktail on a piece of lime and they explained to bite into the lime for the flavour but not eat it). This was our best meal in Madrid and we felt like we truly experienced Spanish tapas. Big thank you to staff and chef!

It was established in 1625, hence it is older than Botin rest, an overrated and overhyped place that we didn't enjoy. We were greeted warmly and escorted to the second floor dining room to a beautiful table with table cloth. We ordered a fine bottle of cava. We had two starters- grilled octopus, and sardines under oil, they were delightfully prepared and delicious. We had a whole striped bass that was grilled to perfection and was moist, tender and filling with grilled tomato and potatoes. We shared a flan for desert which superb. For the quality, it was a reasonable 87 euros, well worth the dining experience.

review_preview: A lot of restaurants in Madrid don't open on Monday evenings so we decided we'd book somewhere prior to the start of our holiday to avoid any disappointment.   Posada de la Villa does open on Monday nights & the Trip Advisor reviews were good so...
review_full: A lot of restaurants in Madrid don't open on Monday evenings so we decided we'd book somewhere prior to the start of our holiday to avoid any disappointment. Posada de la Villa does open on Monday nights & the Trip Advisor reviews were good so we booked online a week before our holiday. Since my dinner companion is particularly fond of lamb we decided in advance we'd have the shared lamb for two which seems to be the restaurant's signature dish. Several reviewers had posted it was the best lamb they'd ever had so we were fairly confident we were in for a good meal. The restaurant was easy to find - easy walking distance from the Plaza Mayor, Calle Cava Baja & the surrounding streets are full of restaurants. No problem with our booking when we arrived & staff were friendly & (thankfully) spoke decent english. This is a nice looking restaurant - traditional & smart but not enough to make you feel uncomfortable. Service was very good - our waiter was attentive without being intrusive & we were well looked after. From memory I think we had house wine, but whatever it was it was good & not expensive. And the lamb? Well it really is as good as everyone says. Easily the best lamb I have ever tasted - absolutely delicious. If you are visiting Madrid I really recommend this place - its attractive, you'll be well looked after & it won't break the bank. Oh & do have the lamb - it really is excellent.
