review_preview: We've now eaten 4 times in this restaurant, so it's about time I did a review! We love this restaurant so much, it's our favourite in Madrid! The first time we visited was for the set lunch menu, we weren't impressed, there was nothing special...
review_full: We've now eaten 4 times in this restaurant, so it's about time I did a review! We love this restaurant so much, it's our favourite in Madrid! The first time we visited was for the set lunch menu, we weren't impressed, there was nothing special about it. We decided we needed to return for the evening menu, and we were so impressed. The menu is a selection of hot and cold 'fusion' tapas. Everything we've tried has been beautifully presented and so tasty. We recommend the Tasting Plate for 2 if it's your first visit, also this is very good value as for 30â‚¬ you get a lot of food - cold starters, hot dishes and dessert. The service is very quick and efficient. The surroundings are artistic and quirky. They play very loud music which is not our type of music as a more mature diner, but we put up with it for the quality of the food. The restaurant is always busy, but it's possible to book online for the first evening sitting at 8.30pm. We've found Sunday evening is much quieter. They are open all day serving different things at different times from breakfast, lunch, afternoon snacks to dinner. The menu and website are all in Spanish, the waiters seem to only speak Spainish also. Perhaps a menu in English would widen this restaurant's appeal, but maybe it doesn't feel it needs to do this!

title_review: Nice and cosy ambience and superb food
review_preview: If you cannot get used to the Spanish 10 PM dinner habit, La Rollerie is an oasis among all the crowded tapas bars and restaurants. You can sit down in quiet and nicely decorated rooms, surrounded by friendly and helpful staff, and you can have...
review_full: If you cannot get used to the Spanish 10 PM dinner habit, La Rollerie is an oasis among all the crowded tapas bars and restaurants. You can sit down in quiet and nicely decorated rooms, surrounded by friendly and helpful staff, and you can have a proper and good evening meal even early in the evening. We were there shortly after the Prado had closed at 8 PM and enjoyed some superb dishes. Pumpkin soup, miniburgers, cheese croquettes, basque omelette and aubergine with honey. All of which you can share if you like to. Next time in Madrid we will definitely return to this very nice place.

The lamb is fine for two very hungry people, and more than enough for three and it is absolutely delicious. The bottle of San Ramon Toro was perfect for the lamb and washed it down well. A very satisfying meal and the surprise at the end is the the bill is so reasonable. I highly recommend this for a romantic dinner, a quiet business discussion or when you just want good food.

review_preview: This was my second time eating here, and to be honest, the first visit last year was good, not brilliant, but good.However, we returned last week on Saturday the 28th September 2017 in the evening and were left very disappointed, and somewhat hungry.Pretty...
review_full: This was my second time eating here, and to be honest, the first visit last year was good, not brilliant, but good. However, we returned last week on Saturday the 28th September 2017 in the evening and were left very disappointed, and somewhat hungry. Pretty much straight away we noticed that the service wasnÂ´t up to much, we were asked what we wanted within minutes of sitting down, but on asking for a couple more minutes to decide, they forgot to come back and ask us. Anyway, that was a minor gripe that can be forgiven. Eventually we ordered black rice and squid and a salmon tart with Italian style toast. It must be pointed out that at this stage people who came in after us had finished their food and were paying when our food finally arrived. As for the wine, I ordered a glass of ribera, which tasted of headache. I later ordered a glass of rioja, and although marginally more drinkable, tasted like it had come from a bottle that had been open for a while. The food looked delicious, but unfortunately I think more time had gone into making it look pretty than how it tasted. The salmon was nice, but as my girlfriend pointed out, you go to a restaurant to eat food that you canÂ´t make at home, and this was something that both of us could have quite easily knocked out in 30 minutes. The accompanying Italian style bread was so hard it was inedible so we left it. I would feel embarrassed serving it up, so IÂ´ve no idea why they thought they could get away serving it. As for the portion size, it was little more than a tapa.  As for the black rice and little squid, it was nice, but again nothing special, and more like a tapa. So, still hungry, we decided to order another main to share between us, we chose a burger as it seemed like a safe option. And then of course came another extremly long wait despite there being only one other couple at this stage that were eating. The burger, when it arrived, was okay, although, and I think this is more of a Spanish thing, the meat was red raw in the middle. What was annoying though was that we could see the staff fawning over a couple in their 70s next to us, with three members of staff serving them, asking how their food was etc. Not once did anyone ask how our food was. ItÂ´s a shame because the restuarant looks dead cute, and is nicely decorated, with a good location.  But the staff could not have been less pleased to serve us and it really showed. IÂ´m not sure if itÂ´s because we looked like tourists, I guess we do, but we both speak Spanish well. It goes without saying that we didnÂ´t tip and went somewhere else for dessert. And itÂ´s not often I leave a bad review, but when I compare it to a meal we had the night before somewhere at a Sushi restaurant in Madrid, we realised how bad it really was. Wont be coming back.

My appetizer was the grilled vegetables, which were so good, I could become a vegetarian. My husband had the Gazpacho and the tripe, both of which were top notch. We then shared the 1/2 roasted lamb, a speciality of the house, and while I almost never eat lamb, this was so tasty and succulent i cleaned my plate. We shared the Caramel Custard. As with everything else it was delicious and not to sweet. We were then served a complimentary after dinner drink. I would place this above Restaurant Boutin as a must go. We arrived early 8pm. The crowds started to arrive 9ish, as is customary in Madrid.

We were two adults with a teen and all enjoyed it equally much. The tapas are inspired by world cuisine, Japanese, Mexican, etc. Each dish is served in its own original way and all of the dishes we tried (many!!!) tasted somewhere between very good and heavenly. The decor is deeply original yet simple, the music perfect, the acoustics good and the waiters funky - but still nice and polite.  All in all, this is one of the best casual eateries I've ever been to.

title_review: Atmospheric, hipster tapas place with delicious healthy options
review_preview: For those who are sick of tapas that have been sitting out for hours, or of unhealthy Iberian ham, this place is highly recommended.  Order 5-6 tapas to share among 2 people.  Prepare to ooh and aha.  Food is made for you from scratch and...
review_full: For those who are sick of tapas that have been sitting out for hours, or of unhealthy Iberian ham, this place is highly recommended. Order 5-6 tapas to share among 2 people. Prepare to ooh and aha. Food is made for you from scratch and there are some fantastic and healthy options - an avocado salad/dip that you mix yourself and that is simply heavenly, and ceviche with avocado served on lime slices that is now my favorite dish here. Less healthy but just as exquisite and recommended are the BOMBA - a potato stuffed with beef stew and covered with pea sauce, unbelievably rich and delicious, and the FRIED GREEN TOMATOES, yes really. They do a modern twist on this dish, with feta and fig jam and arugula salad, so you get sweet, salty, bitter and savory all at once, incredible. Highly, highly recommended.  The only downside is that the quality isn't 100% consistent. Most of the times we've been here, it's been superb, but once or twice the same dishes were served a bit more lazily or tasted a bit less fresh or were not as generously proportioned. I think the main chef had the day off then! But we're happy to risk it, since most of the time it's great.

title_review: Cosy and friendly place for tapas and a meal
review_preview: Emma Cocina is a very popular place as a lot of tourists search around San Miguel market to find it. We went for dinner and were lucky to get a table before it got completely full even with people waiting around the tiny bar to...
review_full: Emma Cocina is a very popular place as a lot of tourists search around San Miguel market to find it. We went for dinner and were lucky to get a table before it got completely full even with people waiting around the tiny bar to get a table. It has simple modern interior and friendly family atmosphere with a local having a drink at the bar. We recommend the kofte and the pork shoulder with mango. The chef is not afraid to experiment and give own twist to traditional recipes. We got complementary starters and wine and even a farewell shots as an apology for delaying some of our orders. Good quality local sausages and cheese, nice wine, good food. Recommend it.

title_review: Lovely restaurant and great roast lamb
review_preview: We had dinner here last week.  The restaurant is lovely.  It has an open wood fired oven on the ground floor where they roast their meat.  We sat upstairs.  Cosy setting and deco.For appetizer, we had the snails and we shared the roast lamb...
review_full: We had dinner here last week. The restaurant is lovely. It has an open wood fired oven on the ground floor where they roast their meat. We sat upstairs. Cosy setting and deco. For appetizer, we had the snails and we shared the roast lamb which was for 2. The snail was good and we loved the roast lamb. Very well done. For drinks, my husband had a glass of wine and we shared half a jug of Sangria. I like the way they mix their Sangria here, sweet and fruity. I had one at a previous place the night before which was bitter which I didn't really like. This is a lovely place to have a local Portuguese dinner while in Madrid. We spent about EUR80+ which we thought was very reasonable.

Would definitely return, if I was in Madrid again.

title_review: The epitome of comfort food Madrid style!
review_preview: Roast 28 day old lamb in a huge wood burning oven dating to 1642! Simply amazing! We have been there twice, first in November 2012 and then 2 days ago. Everything was exactly as we remembered, even the same waiter, Javier. It is the kind...
review_full: Roast 28 day old lamb in a huge wood burning oven dating to 1642! Simply amazing! We have been there twice, first in November 2012 and then 2 days ago. Everything was exactly as we remembered, even the same waiter, Javier. It is the kind of place that you dream about for an entire year when you know that you are going back! The garlic soup with egg, the roast potatoes, the roast mushrooms all wonderful. Even though the restaurant has a very large and superb wine list, the staff recommend the very inexpensive house red at 16.5 euros from a winery on the outskirts of Madrid toward Toledo, and it is simply delicious. It is not necessary to spend any more. The service is friendly, professional and very attentive without being overbearing. Can't wait to go back again!

title_review: Wonderful atmosphere, service, and food selection!
review_preview: We discovered this gem quite by accident and were delighted with our find.  Walking by in the afternoon, we noticed a private get-together was underway and decided to return, at least for a drink in the bar.  Once inside, we were immersed in the character...
review_full: We discovered this gem quite by accident and were delighted with our find. Walking by in the afternoon, we noticed a private get-together was underway and decided to return, at least for a drink in the bar. Once inside, we were immersed in the character of the establishment and decided to stay for dinner. Not only was the service impeccable, the food was wonderful! Our lamb was perhaps the best anywhere and the enormous veal chop was tasty. The clientele was obviously Spanish as opposed to being mainly tourists although it is a short walk from Plaza Mayor. I definitely suggest giving it a try. Having said all these positive things, let me mention that we returned for the house specialty, Cocido Madrileno. While in Madrid, there was an article how one should try the "capital's signature dish". I am sure Posada de la Villa prepared it to perfection; however, no one in our party was particularly impressed with this stew even after having to order it a day in advance! We regretted not having tried another menu item.

So we decided, let's just have a bacalao each, eat it quickly, then leave.... whcih wouldn't have been bad trade for the place, considering that we usually paid around 2,50 Euro for one bacalao (no, we don't know the price, we were never given a bill). Anyway, I made it to the counter, asked for 2 bacalaos and I was told I had to have a drink. I explained that I didn't even have space to move my arm, let alone have this drink with some decent and calm way as not to spill it.... to no avail. We decided we would not leave 5 Euros there and headed to La Labra, which we had always loved to an equal amount. But things were nicer there, there was some outside seating space and we were not forced to buy a drink, although, the evening being so nice, we naturally did.  Considering that a tajada at Labra is 1,25 Euro we got ourselves a very good deal, I suppose, and without an unfriendly barman telling us to gulp down a drink ;)

title_review: Go for the salt cod (bacalao) fritters
review_preview: A small place in La Latina, very popular with locals who were already lining up for the 7pm reopening of the bar following the after lunch closure and the place filled up really quickly.Service is friendly and quick. Most people have a small draft...
review_full: A small place in La Latina, very popular with locals who were already lining up for the 7pm reopening of the bar following the after lunch closure and the place filled up really quickly. Service is friendly and quick. Most people have a small draft beer and a cod fritter each. The fritters are fantastic: they are big, flaky, salty, and succulent on the inside. The batter is well-made and tasty and goes very well with the fish, which is of very good quality. They also do a couple of other tapas, I tried a small, fried tuna empanada and a piece of battered and fried sardine (or herring - this was in a different batter to the cod that wasn't as good). These were okay, but a bit greasy and nothing special, so I would suggest following the locals: to have a drink and a piece of cod (or several...) and move on to another bar.  Casa Revuelta is more of a bar than a restaurant and there isn't a full menu, so you couldn't have an entire sit down tapas lunch or dinner, but it's perfect for a drink and a snack or as part of a tapas crawl. Well worth a trip for the fritters, the lively, fun, boisterous atmosphere and an authentic Madrid experience.

title_review: Frills no - but the best fried fish
review_preview: I had read reviews of the cafe before deciding to try it - neither the reveiws nor thecafe disappointed.  Don't expect a seat at table here - the locals grab the ones that there are early and you will usually have to find a space...
review_full: I had read reviews of the cafe before deciding to try it - neither the reveiws nor thecafe disappointed. Don't expect a seat at table here - the locals grab the ones that there are early and you will usually have to find a space at the counter to eat your fish. But it sure is worth it because the bacalau is very nice and at 3 euros a piece was not overly expensive. Wash it down with a beer or wine and you are ready to move on to the next attraction - or the next bar if that's what you want. Service is quick and, judging from the number of discarded napkins on the floor, pretty unrelenting. Don't be put off - the place has no need for airs and graces - just enjoy!

title_review: Wonderful food in a comfortable setting
review_preview: We discovered this small restaurant near the Mercado de San Miguel and loved its food, relaxed setting, and welcoming staff. Located on a side street, the Emma Cocina has a fine selection of beers and wines. With a small bar in one corner, there are...
review_full: We discovered this small restaurant near the Mercado de San Miguel and loved its food, relaxed setting, and welcoming staff. Located on a side street, the Emma Cocina has a fine selection of beers and wines. With a small bar in one corner, there are a limited number of tables so arrive early to snag a good place. The food is varied with appetizers, salads, and main dishes. We loved the croquetas and salmorejo. On the evening visited, after our appetizers, we ordered a delicious salad with pears, caramelized nuts, and Stilton cheese. For main dishes we selected the "miniburgers" and a "tallÃ­n de cordero" (lamb, couscous, almonds, plums) to share. The meal was superb, tasty, and good portions. There is a limited selection of desserts--I opted for a lemon custard tart, topped with raspberries. I was not disappointed, and definitely, we need to return to try the other options and enjoy the atmosphere.

review_preview: Walking past this little Madrid bar, you'd never guess that they served the most tasty salted cod fritters or 'bacalao'. It is just a short distance from Plaza Mayor.We had seen this place on a foodie video on Youtube. We were in Madrid for...
review_full: Walking past this little Madrid bar, you'd never guess that they served the most tasty salted cod fritters or 'bacalao'. It is just a short distance from Plaza Mayor. We had seen this place on a foodie video on Youtube. We were in Madrid for 4 nights and visited twice.  On our first visit, about 19:30, it was jam packed with locals, doing what they do best, eating tapas with a beer/wine and having a chat. We managed to get a spot at the bar. We had a couple of cana (small beers) and also tried the vermut. They also serve red wine in small cups. We ordered 2 bacalao each. Absolutely to die for. Crispy batter with melt in the mouth fish inside. Don't be put off by the salted cod, it's not overly salty, tasted perfectly seasoned. Bacalao was â‚¬3 per piece, drinks were a mere â‚¬1.50. We paid at the end and gave â‚¬5 tip, the owner then gave us 2 drinks in return! Humble owners who know what they offer. An absolute must if you're in Madrid.

Many of our tour lunched in the Mercado, which was tempting but very, very busy. We ended up at Emma. It was a quiet, calm oasis with nice tapas. We shared a tasty green salad with gorgonzola, pear and balsamic, and a couple of tapas which were very well done. The cost was not outrageous and the service was excellent. Emma Cocina is a nice oasis of calm in the middle of a very busy area. Recommended.

title_review: Fabulous, one of my best meals in Spain, and very kind to host a large group
review_preview: We had an outstanding experience at Emma Cocina when visiting Madrid in June.  I had a large group of university students with me, most of whom had arrived in Spain on a long-haul flight within the previous 12 hours.  Being tired and jet-lagged, there was...
review_full: We had an outstanding experience at Emma Cocina when visiting Madrid in June. I had a large group of university students with me, most of whom had arrived in Spain on a long-haul flight within the previous 12 hours. Being tired and jet-lagged, there was no way they were going to survive until 9pm or so, the usual time a restaurant in Madrid would be serving dinner. Emma very kindly agreed to open early for us, and to seat all 28 of us in her small restaurant. Vanessa was on the front desk and managed the evening with our guests - she was amazingly and generously helpful. Her English was excellent, which helped a great deal as my Spanish is pretty basic. A couple of English-language menus were on hand, which made it easy for everyone in the group to order. The food was outstanding. I had the slow-cooked pork cheeks, which were beautiful. The salad course was wonderful - possibly the best I've ever had. Everything on the menu looked wonderful. It was a little more expensive than the usual 'menu of the day' that many Spanish bars and restaurants offer. But it was very good value for what they served. 28 Euros per person covered a number of tapas plates for entre, an enormous salad course, a fantastic a la carte main course, and drinks. We took the students out for churros for dessert, though we would have had a better end to our meal if we'd stayed at Emma's. This was definitely the food highlight of my stay in Madrid. We returned a few days later as a smaller group, but I wish we could have come back more often. We'll definitely return when in Madrid.

review_preview: We visited Madrid, Spain, during Christmas of 2014. We decided to eat at La Posada de la Villa (restaurant and inn). The restaurant has been in existence since 1642. The restaurant is located in the old Madrid, south of the beautiful Plaza Mayor. The place...
review_full: We visited Madrid, Spain, during Christmas of 2014. We decided to eat at La Posada de la Villa (restaurant and inn). The restaurant has been in existence since 1642. The restaurant is located in the old Madrid, south of the beautiful Plaza Mayor. The place has been well kept and remodeled. The furniture gives the place a somehow rustic, historic character. We used the second floor dinning area. My parents went up in a convenient elevator. The stairs were comfortable fot the rest of the group. The food was great. Prior to order anything, they served complimentary "croquetas" for everybody. A fried dough made with wheat flour, soft in the inside, not too salty, not greasy at all. Following Dimitri, our waiter, recomendations, I ordered apetizers, three plates, to distribute along the never ending table. Each plate was filled with a variety made up of cured ham, salami, chorizo, and manchego cheese (cured cheese made with sheepÂ´s milk). I wanted to share also one portion of "callos a la madrileÃ±a". This is a local typical dish made with stomach and other parts of cows or pigs cooked in a delicious juice with condiments, portions of chorizo, and morcilla (blood sausage). I really liked it. My wife (canadian from Montreal) did not want to try it, and she missed a great experience of flavors, and textures difficult to explain with words. For the main dish, I followed DimitriÂ´s suggestion, and tried lamb. It was tender and the flavor subtle and delicious. I also tried some mushrooms ordered by my father (already 89-year-old and still going) who ordered some fish later. Some ordered veggi dishes. The experience was great as a whole. The meal was accompanied by my favorite red wine, Marques de Riscal (rioja). The prize for 13, with appetizers for everybody, 5 bottles of Marques de Riscal (maybe 6), coffe and dessert, and tip, was about 800 US dollars. I was busy talking and missed dessert. My son, now 16, "all american" palate, enjoyed "leche frita". As we were leaving, a small, old shaped key was given to everyone of us. This souvenir is given to all the customers, as if it was the key to enter the inn. It was a great experience and the food was rated "very good" by everybody in the party. The service was great. By the way, the restrooms were clean. Maybe it was the company and the great time we had, but I am not able to recall any minuses.

title_review: We have a winner! Delicious food close to Plaza Mayor and San Miguel Market
review_preview: If you find yourself in the Plaza Mayor and find the restaurants around the plaza too touristy and San Miguel Market too busy and/or touristy than stop by Emma Cucina for a delicious meal.  We were looking for a place for dinner after ending our...
review_full: If you find yourself in the Plaza Mayor and find the restaurants around the plaza too touristy and San Miguel Market too busy and/or touristy than stop by Emma Cucina for a delicious meal.  We were looking for a place for dinner after ending our walking tour in Plaza Mayor. Had some difficulty locating a place with decent reviews and not too pricey. Emma Cucina hit the spot. Our party of four had to wait 15 min for a table to clear - the place is small, it had tables for 2 open but not a table for four. We ordered a variety of starters (crispy wrapped feta and spinach, tempura asparagus) and mains (ravioli with stilton sauce, tangine chicken, pork cheeks with mashed potatoes and a full plate of croquettes). The croquettes were excellent. The pork cheeks with mashed potatoes were melt in your mouth luxury - order with a glass of the tempernello wine that the cheeks were cooked in. All the food with 2 cokes and 2 glasses of wine were 80 Euros

review_preview: Yum. This place is right in one of the entrances to Plaza Mayor. You can smell the Calamari before you even arrive. The sandwiches are huge and overflowing with perfectly cooked calamari. They are so big that you begin to worry that you may not...
review_full: Yum. This place is right in one of the entrances to Plaza Mayor. You can smell the Calamari before you even arrive. The sandwiches are huge and overflowing with perfectly cooked calamari. They are so big that you begin to worry that you may not be able to fit that thing in your mouth. But, where there's a will, there's a way. Pair that sandwich with an ice cold beer and you are in heaven. If you go on a nice sunny day on the weekend chances are you have to stand outside and eat with all the rest of the people, mostly Spanish people who trek into town to have a great sandwich. They have other sandwiches, like beicon, morcilla (blood sausage) chorizo, and others. The service is quick and the guys there treat you like family! To top it off the sandwich is only 2.70 euros. What a bargain.

title_review: A gem! - the best calamares with authentic neighborhood ambience!
review_preview: This tiny tapas bar is located in an alley just off the Plaza Mayor and would be missed if you weren't looking for it. It was our first meal in Spain, and it set the bar high especially for calamares! The kids devoured their calamares...
review_full: This tiny tapas bar is located in an alley just off the Plaza Mayor and would be missed if you weren't looking for it. It was our first meal in Spain, and it set the bar high especially for calamares! The kids devoured their calamares bocadillos (little sandwiches). I had the classic Spanish torta (potato/egg tort) and my husband had a jamon bocadillo, all downed with ice-cold cerveza. The staff spoke NO English but were extremely warm and friendly. The place was half full about 6 people in back (that's how small it was) at 2pm and NO tourists. All locals, mostly an older crowd. There were many who came to eat standing at the stainless steel bar ordering a plate of calamares or a bocadillo with cerveza, then would leave within 15minutes to eat & chat. The staff seemed to know everyone who came in -- like a local neighborhood hang out. An elderly couple came in to eat standing up and started talking to us in Spanish as if they knew us. It was really amazing. It didn't matter that we were obviously foreigners trying to speak Spanish unsuccessfully. It was such a great introduction to Spain and Madrid. I'd definitely come back here!

The bocadillo was served without sauce or a lemon. We had to ask for a slice of lemon. The taste of the calamares was good. The patatas bravas were well seasoned (perhaps a little too salty). Overall it was a correctly priced and tasty lunch. In this neighbourhood it was a nice quick stop in a typical Spanish environment.

title_review: Best Calamari Sandwich at Plaza Mayor
review_preview: There are numerous restaurants at Plaza Mayor selling calamari sandwiches, but in our opinion, this one is the best. Specializing in the sandwiches, they had a constant stream of customers flowing in and out of the store. Service was quick and with a smile, the...
review_full: There are numerous restaurants at Plaza Mayor selling calamari sandwiches, but in our opinion, this one is the best. Specializing in the sandwiches, they had a constant stream of customers flowing in and out of the store. Service was quick and with a smile, the sandwiches were tasty and most of all, it was great value. Highly recommended, and if you love a taste of the local culture, then this is the place to go. We will definitely be back when we return to Madrid.

I will definitely be recommending this dining establishment to those friends of mine who are looking for an evening of fine dining.

review_preview: Obviously a local institution and popular with tourist groups. A lovely old building on 3 floors with bags of atmosphere. They run a very efficient operation here. Service was quick,slick and professional. Despite the large numbers here,even at tourist eating time of 8.30, we had...
review_full: Obviously a local institution and popular with tourist groups. A lovely old building on 3 floors with bags of atmosphere. They run a very efficient operation here. Service was quick,slick and professional. Despite the large numbers here,even at tourist eating time of 8.30, we had our orders taken quickly and our food was delivered promptly. My wife had some lovely fresh green asparagus for her starter,an immense portion. I had stuffed peppers and I was worried I had eyes bigger than my stomach. However,the peppers were very light and seemed to melt in my mouth.For our main course we had the signature roast lamb - truly excellent. If you go here,and you would be remiss not to,, have nothing to eat for the earlier part of the day !. We liked this restaurant a lot and it is easy to see why it is successful

review_full: While on a walking tour of Madrid, our guide (Tatiana from Ogo Free Walking Tours) recommended "La Ideal" as the best calamari sandwich in all of Madrid, and for less than 3Euro. Neither of us are fond of calamari, but we decided afterwards to give it a go - and it was amazing. Freshly cooked, and not at all rubbery as with calamari that I've tried previously. La Ideal has made calamari converts out of us.  Why not try it? You could be amazed.
